Kemendikbud : PAUD Cegah Perilaku Beresiko Pada Remaja
05 Nov 2019, 18:36 by Rini Hairani


Kemendikbud : PAUD Cegah Perilaku Beresiko Pada Remaja

KBRN, Jakarta :  Kementerian Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan melenggarakan seminar Kemendikbud melalui Direktorat Jenderal PAUD dan Pendidikan Masyarakat menyelenggarakan konferensi Internasional Pendidikan Anak Usia Dini (PAUD) di Hotel Millenium Jakarta, Selasa (05/11/2019).Direktur Jenderal dan Dikmas Kemdikbud Harris Iskandar mengatakan pembangunan pendidikan berkelanjutan dibutuhkan untuk mencegah perilaku berisiko para remaja di Indonesia."Pembangunan pendidikan berkelanjutan bertujuan untuk memastikan pendidikan yang berkualitas, inklusif dan adil serta mempromosikan kesempatan belajar seumur hidup untuk semua," kata Harris. Menurut Harris,  data perilaku berisiko para remaja di Indonesia masih tinggi. Perilaku tersebut antara lain kebiasaan merokok, tindak kekerasan atau perundungan, pornografi, narkoba, dan radikalisme.Berdasarkan data Global School Health Survey (GSHS) Kementerian Kesehatan pada 2017, siswa SMP dan SMA/K laki-laki yang merokok, katanya, tercatat sebanyak 22 persen, pernah mengonsumsi minuman beralkohol sebanyak 7,3 persen, pernah mengonsumsi narkoba 2,6 persen dan pernah menjadi korban perundungan 24 persen.Kemudian, menurut data Kemendikbud pada 2018, dari sekitar 98 persen dari total siswa SMP dan SMA/K, 6,3 persen di antaranya terkena adiksi pornografi ringan dan 0,07 persen terkena adiksi cukup berat.Sementara itu, data Asosiasi Penyelenggara Jasa Internet Indonesia (APJII) pada 2019, penetrasi pengguna internet di Indonesia mencapai 171 juta orang atau sekitar 65 persen dari populasi dengan 19,6 persen di antaranya mengakses internet lebih dari delapan jam per hari.Hal tersebut, katanya, membutuhkan perhatian serius terutama dari keluarga dan sekolah."Keluarga perlu memastikan agar anak-anak mereka terbebas dari masalah ini yang dapat mengganggu pencapaian pendidikan," ungkap Harris. Salah satu upaya yang dibutuhkan untuk mencegah perilaku berisiko para remaja di Indonesia, katanya, adalah membangun pendidikan berkelanjutan yang bertujuan untuk memastikan pendidikan yang berkualitas, inklusif dan adil.Tujuan tersebut, katanya, secara khusus mencakup akses dan layanan yang sama bagi semua anak laki-laki dan perempuan guna memperoleh layanan pendidikan yang berkualitas sebagai indikator keberhasilan."Ini menandakan ortodoksi global yang memandang pendidikan anak usia dini dan pendidikan keluarga sebagai elemen penting yang memastikan perkembangan suatu bangsa," pungkas Haris. Tema seminar internasional ini adalah “Melampaui Akses dan Partisipasi: Meningkatkan Kualitas Pendidikan dan Pengembangan Anak Usia Dini sebagai Media untuk Mencapai Tujuan Pembangunan Berkelanjutan 2030”.Secara keseluruhan seminar dihadiri sebanyak 500 orang. Seminar ini diikuti oleh 15 negara dan dihadiri oleh perwakilan dari Kementerian Pendidikan, akademisi, praktisi dan penggiat PAUD dari Afganistan, Australia, Banglades, Filipina, Kamboja, Korea Selatan, Madagaskar, Maroko, Jepang, Vietnam, Perancis, Tajikistan, Thailand, Timor Leste, dan Yaman. Peserta dari dalam negeri berasal dari para penggiat PAUD dan pendidikan keluarga, akademisi, pendidik, tenaga kependidikan, dan organisasi mitra. (RH)

Ministry of Education and Culture: PAUD Preventing Risk Behavior in Adolescents
05 Nov 2019, 18:36 by Rini Hairani


Ministry of Education and Culture: PAUD Preventing Risk Behavior in Adolescents

KBRN, Jakarta: The Ministry of Education and Culture held a Ministry of Education and Culture seminar through the Directorate General of PAUD and Community Education holding an International Conference on Early Childhood Education (PAUD) at the Millennium Hotel in Jakarta, Tuesday (11/05/2019). Director General of Education and Culture Kemdikbud Harris Iskandar said Continuing education development is needed to prevent risky behavior of young people in Indonesia. "Sustainable education development aims to ensure quality, inclusive and equitable education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all," Harris said. According to Harris, data on risk behavior of adolescents in Indonesia is still high. These behaviors include smoking, violence or harassment, pornography, drugs and radicalism. Based on data from the Ministry of Health's Global School Health Survey (GSHS) in 2017, male and female middle and high school students who smoke, he said, recorded 22 percent, had consumed alcoholic beverages as much as 7.3 percent, had consumed drugs 2.6 percent and had been a victim of abuse of 24 percent. Then, according to data from the Ministry of Education and Culture in 2018, of about 98 percent of the total junior and senior high school students, 6, 3 percent of them are exposed to mild pornography addiction and 0.07 percent of them are quite addicted. Meanwhile, data from the Indonesian Internet Service Providers Association (APJII) in 2019, the penetration of internet users in Indonesia reaches 171 million people or about 65 percent of the population with 19 , 6 percent of them access the internet more than eight hours per day. This, he said, requires serious attention, especially from families and schools. " "We need to ensure that their children are free from this problem which can interfere with educational achievement," said Harris. One of the efforts needed to prevent risky behavior of young people in Indonesia, he said, is to build sustainable education that aims to ensure quality, inclusive and equitable education. The goals, he said, specifically include equal access and services for all boys men and women in order to obtain quality education services as an indicator of success. "This marks a global orthodoxy that views early childhood education and family education as important elements that ensure the development of a nation," concluded Haris. The theme of this international seminar is "Beyond Access and Participation: Improving the Quality of Education and Early Childhood Development as a Media to Achieve the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals". The overall seminar was attended by 500 people. The seminar was attended by 15 countries and attended by representatives from the Ministry of Education, academics, practitioners and PAUD activists from Afghanistan, Australia, Bangladesh, the Philippines, Cambodia, South Korea, Madagascar, Morocco, Japan, Vietnam, France, Tajikistan, Thailand, Timor Leste , and Yemen. Domestic participants come from PAUD activists and family education, academics, educators, education personnel, and partner organizations. (RH)
